function Reverse_Find (Container : Vector;{"\n"}                       Item      : Element_Type;{"\n"}                       Position  : Cursor := No_Element){"\n"}   return Cursor{"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} Position = No_Element or else{"\n"}                Has_Element (Container, Position){"\n"}                   or else raise Program_Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} (if Reverse_Find'Result /= No_Element{"\n"}                 then Has_Element (Container, Reverse_Find'Result));{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>222/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0264-1", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p> Reverse_Find searches the elements of Container for an element equal to Item (using the generic formal equality operator). The search starts at the last element if Position equals No_Element, and at the element designated by Position otherwise. It proceeds towards the first element of Container. If no equal element is found, then Reverse_Find returns No_Element. Otherwise, it returns a cursor designating the first equal element encountered.<br /></p>

<MarginText>223/2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Contains (Container : Vector;{"\n"}                   Item      : Element_Type) return Boolean;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>224/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Equivalent to Has_Element (Find (Container, Item)).<br /></p>

<p><em>Paragraphs 225 and 226 were moved above.</em> <br /></p>

<MarginText>227/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Iterate{"\n"}  (Container : in Vector;{"\n"}   Process   : not null access procedure (Position : in Cursor)){"\n"}   with Allows_Exit;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>228/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0265-1"]} />
<p>Invokes Process.<strong>all</strong> with a cursor that designates each element in Container, in index order. Tampering with the cursors of Container is prohibited during the execution of a call on Process.<strong>all</strong>. Any exception raised by Process.<strong>all</strong> is propagated.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>228.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<strong></strong>The purpose of the &ldquo;tamper with the cursors&rdquo; check is to prevent erroneous execution from the Position parameter of Process.<strong>all</strong> becoming invalid. This check takes place when the operations that tamper with the cursors of the container are called. The check cannot be made later (say in the body of Iterate), because that could cause the Position cursor to be invalid and potentially cause execution to become erroneous -- defeating the purpose of the check.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>228.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
There is no check needed if an attempt is made to insert or delete nothing (that is, Count = 0 or Length(Item) = 0).<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>228.c/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The check is easy to implement: each container needs a counter. The counter is incremented when Iterate is called, and decremented when Iterate completes. If the counter is nonzero when an operation that inserts or deletes is called, Finalize is called, or one of the other operations in the list occurs, Program_Error is raised. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>229/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Reverse_Iterate{"\n"}  (Container : in Vector;{"\n"}   Process   : not null access procedure (Position : in Cursor)){"\n"}   with Allows_Exit;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>230/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0212-1"]} />
<p>Iterates over the elements in Container as per procedure Iterate, except that elements are traversed in reverse index order.<br /></p>

<MarginText>230.1/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0212-1", "AI12-0266-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Iterate (Container : in Vector){"\n"}   return Vector_Iterator_Interfaces.Parallel_Reversible_Iterator 'Class{"\n"}   with Post   ={">"} Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Container);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>230.2/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1", "AI05-0265-1", "AI05-0269-1", "AI12-0266-1"]} />
<p>Iterate returns an  iterator object (see <a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#Subclause_5.5.1">5.5.1</a>) that will generate a value for a loop parameter (see <a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#Subclause_5.5.2">5.5.2</a>) designating each node in Container, starting with the first node and moving the cursor as per the Next function when used as a forward iterator, and starting with the last node and moving the cursor as per the Previous function when used as a reverse iterator, and processing all nodes concurrently when used as a parallel iterator. Tampering with the cursors of Container is prohibited while the iterator object exists (in particular, in the <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.1#S0166">sequence_of_statements</a></code> of the <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#S0178">loop_statement</a></code> whose <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#S0183">iterator_specification</a></code> denotes this object). The iterator object needs finalization.<br /></p>

<MarginText>230.3/5</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Iterate (Container : in Vector; Start : in Cursor){"\n"}   return Vector_Iterator_Interfaces.Reversible_Iterator'Class{"\n"}   with Pre    ={">"} (Start /= No_Element{"\n"}                        or else raise Constraint_Error) and then{"\n"}                     (Has_Element (Container, Start){"\n"}                        or else raise Program_Error),{"\n"}        Post   ={">"} Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Container);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>230.4/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1", "AI05-0262-1", "AI05-0265-1", "AI05-0269-1", "AI12-0212-1"]} />
<p> Iterate returns a reversible iterator object (see <a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#Subclause_5.5.1">5.5.1</a>) that will generate a value for a loop parameter (see <a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#Subclause_5.5.2">5.5.2</a>) designating each node in Container, starting with the node designated by Start and moving the cursor as per the Next function when used as a forward iterator, or moving the cursor as per the Previous function when used as a reverse iterator. Tampering with the cursors of Container is prohibited while the iterator object exists (in particular, in the <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.1#S0166">sequence_of_statements</a></code> of the <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#S0178">loop_statement</a></code> whose <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#S0183">iterator_specification</a></code> denotes this object). The iterator object needs finalization.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>230.a/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<strong></strong>Exits are allowed from the loops created using the iterator objects. In particular, to stop the iteration at a particular cursor, just add <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>230.b/3</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
exit when Cur = Stop;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>230.c/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
in the body of the loop (assuming that Cur is the loop parameter and Stop is the cursor that you want to stop at). <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>231/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0044-1", "AI05-0262-1"]} />
<p>The actual function for the generic formal function "{"<"}" of Generic_Sorting is expected to return the same value each time it is called with a particular pair of element values. It should define a strict weak ordering relationship (see <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18">A.18</a>); it should not modify Container. If the actual for "{"<"}" behaves in some other manner, the behavior of the subprograms of Generic_Sorting are unspecified. The number of times the subprograms of Generic_Sorting call "{"<"}" is unspecified.<br /></p>

<MarginText>232/2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Is_Sorted (Container : Vector) return Boolean;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>233/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Returns True if the elements are sorted smallest first as determined by the generic formal "{"<"}" operator; otherwise, Is_Sorted returns False. Any exception raised during evaluation of "{"<"}" is propagated.<br /></p>

<MarginText>234/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Sort (Container : in out Vector){"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} not Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Container){"\n"}                    or else raise Program_Error;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>235/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Reorders the elements of Container such that the elements are sorted smallest first as determined by the generic formal "{"<"}" operator provided. Any exception raised during evaluation of "{"<"}" is propagated.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>235.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>This implies swapping the elements, usually including an intermediate copy. This means that the elements will usually be copied. (As with Swap, if the implementation can do this some other way, it is allowed to.) Since the elements are nonlimited, this usually will not be a problem. Note that there is  below that the implementation should use a sort that minimizes copying of elements.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>235.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The sort is not required to be stable (and the fast algorithm required will not be stable). If a stable sort is needed, the user can include the original location of the element as an extra "sort key". We considered requiring the implementation to do that, but it is mostly extra overhead -- usually there is something already in the element that provides the needed stability. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>236/5</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Merge (Target  : in out Vector;{"\n"}                 Source  : in out Vector){"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} (not Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Target){"\n"}                   or else raise Program_Error) and then{"\n"}                (not Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Source){"\n"}                   or else raise Program_Error) and then{"\n"}                (Length (Target) {"<"}= Maximum_Length - Length (Source){"\n"}                   or else raise Constraint_Error) and then{"\n"}                ((Length (Source) = 0 or else{"\n"}                   not Target'Has_Same_Storage (Source)){"\n"}                   or else raise Program_Error),{"\n"}        Post ={">"} (declare{"\n"}                    Result_Length : constant Count_Type :={"\n"}                       Length (Source)'Old + Length (Target)'Old;{"\n"}                 begin{"\n"}                    (Length (Source) = 0 and then{"\n"}                     Length (Target) = Result_Length and then{"\n"}                     Capacity (Target) {">"}= Result_Length));{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>237/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0021-1", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p> Merge removes elements from Source and inserts them into Target; afterwards, Target contains the union of the elements that were initially in Source and Target; Source is left empty. If Target and Source are initially sorted smallest first, then Target is ordered smallest first as determined by the generic formal "{"<"}" operator; otherwise, the order of elements in Target is unspecified. Any exception raised during evaluation of "{"<"}" is propagated.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>237.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<strong></strong>It is a bounded error if either of the vectors is unsorted, see below. The bounded error can be recovered by sorting Target after the merge call, or the vectors can be pretested with Is_Sorted. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>237.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>The Merge operation will usually require copying almost all of the elements. One implementation strategy would be to extend Target to the appropriate length, then copying elements from the back of the vectors working towards the front. An alternative approach would be to allocate a new internal data array of the appropriate length, copy the elements into it in an appropriate order, and then replacing the data array in Target with the temporary. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>237.1/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0111-1"]} />
<p>The nested package Vectors.Stable provides a type Stable.Vector that represents a <em>stable</em> vector, which is one that cannot grow and shrink. Such a vector can be created by calling the To_Vector or Copy functions, or by establishing a <em>stabilized view</em> of an ordinary vector.<br /></p>

<MarginText>237.2/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0111-1"]} />
<p>The subprograms of package Containers.Vectors that have a parameter or result of type Vector are included in the nested package Stable with the same specification, except that the following are omitted:<br /></p>

<MarginText>237.3/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0111-1", "AI12-0400-1"]} />
<p>Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited, Tampering_With_Elements_Prohibited, Reserve_Capacity, Assign, Move, Insert, Insert_Space, Insert_Vector, Append, Append_Vector, Prepend, Prepend_Vector, Clear, Delete, Delete_First, Delete_Last, and Set_Length <br /></p>

<MarginText>237.4/5</MarginText>
<p>The generic package Generic_Sorting is also included with the same specification, except that Merge is omitted.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>237.b.1/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<strong></strong>The names Vector and Cursor mean the types declared in the nested package in these subprogram specifications. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>237.b.2/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<strong></strong>The omitted routines are those that tamper with cursors or elements (or test that state). The model is that it is impossible to tamper with cursors or elements of a stable view since no such operations are included. Thus tampering checks are not needed for a stable view, and we omit the operations associated with those checks. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>237.5/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0111-1"]} />
<p>The operations of this package are equivalent to those for ordinary vectors, except that the calls to Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited and Tampering_With_Elements_Prohibited that occur in preconditions are replaced by False, and any that occur in postconditions are replaced by True.<br /></p>

<MarginText>237.6/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0111-1", "AI12-0439-1"]} />
<p>If a stable vector is declared with the Base discriminant designating a pre-existing ordinary vector, the stable vector represents a stabilized view of the underlying ordinary vector, and any operation on the stable vector is reflected on the underlying ordinary vector. While a stabilized view exists, any operation that tampers with elements performed on the underlying vector is prohibited. The finalization of a stable vector that provides such a view removes this restriction on the underlying ordinary vector [(though some other restriction can exist due to other concurrent iterations or stabilized views)].<br /></p>

<MarginText>237.7/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0111-1", "AI12-0438-1"]} />
<p>If a stable vector is declared without specifying Base, the object is necessarily initialized. The initializing expression of the stable vector, [typically a call on To_Vector or Copy], determines the Length of the vector. The Length of a stable vector never changes after initialization.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>237.c/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0438-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="proof">
<strong></strong>Initialization is required as the type is indefinite, see <a href="../AA-3/AA-3.3#Subclause_3.3.1">3.3.1</a>. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Bounded (Run-Time) Errors

<MarginText>238/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0212-1"]} />
<p>Reading the value of an empty element by calling Element, Query_Element, Update_Element, Constant_Reference, Reference, Swap, Is_Sorted, Sort, Merge, "=", Find, or Reverse_Find is a bounded error. The implementation may treat the element as having any normal value (see <a href="../AA-13/AA-13.9#Subclause_13.9.1">13.9.1</a>) of the element type, or raise Constraint_Error or Program_Error before modifying the vector.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>238.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<strong></strong>For instance, a default initialized element could be returned. Or some previous value of an element. But returning random junk is not allowed if the type has default initial value(s).<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>238.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Assignment and streaming of empty elements are <strong>not</strong> bounded errors. This is consistent with regular composite types, for which assignment and streaming of uninitialized components do not cause a bounded error, but reading the uninitialized component does cause a bounded error.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>238.c/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
There are other operations which are defined in terms of the operations listed above. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>239/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Calling Merge in an instance of Generic_Sorting with either Source or Target not ordered smallest first using the provided generic formal "{"<"}" operator is a bounded error. Either Program_Error is raised after Target is updated as described for Merge, or the operation works as defined.<br /></p>

<MarginText>239.1/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0022-1", "AI05-0248-1"]} />
<p>It is a bounded error for the actual function associated with a generic formal subprogram, when called as part of an operation of this package, to tamper with elements of any Vector parameter of the operation. Either Program_Error is raised, or the operation works as defined on the value of the Vector either prior to, or subsequent to, some or all of the modifications to the Vector.<br /></p>

<MarginText>239.2/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0027-1"]} />
<p>It is a bounded error to call any subprogram declared in the visible part of Containers.Vectors when the associated container has been finalized. If the operation takes Container as an <strong>in out</strong> parameter, then it raises Constraint_Error or Program_Error. Otherwise, the operation either proceeds as it would for an empty container, or it raises Constraint_Error or Program_Error.<br /></p>

<MarginText>240/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>A Cursor value is <em>ambiguous</em> if any of the following have occurred since it was created:<br /></p>

<MarginText>241/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0400-1"]} />
<ul>
<li>Insert, Insert_Space, Insert_Vector, or Delete has been called on the vector that contains the element the cursor designates with an index value (or a cursor designating an element at such an index value) less than or equal to the index value of the element designated by the cursor; or<br /></li>
<MarginText>242/2</MarginText>
<li>The vector that contains the element it designates has been passed to the Sort or Merge procedures of an instance of Generic_Sorting, or to the Reverse_Elements procedure.<br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>243/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>It is a bounded error to call any subprogram other than "=" or Has_Element declared in Containers.Vectors with an ambiguous (but not invalid, see below) cursor parameter. Possible results are:<br /></p>

<MarginText>244/2</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>The cursor may be treated as if it were No_Element;<br /></li>
<MarginText>245/2</MarginText>
<li>The cursor may designate some element in the vector (but not necessarily the element that it originally designated);<br /></li>
<MarginText>246/2</MarginText>
<li>Constraint_Error may be raised; or<br /></li>
<MarginText>247/2</MarginText>
<li>Program_Error may be raised.<br /></li>
</ul>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>247.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<strong></strong>Cursors are made ambiguous if an Insert or Delete occurs that moves the elements in the internal array including the designated ones. After such an operation, the cursor probably still designates an element (although it might not after a deletion), but it is a <em>different</em> element. That violates the definition of cursor &mdash; it designates a particular element.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>247.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
For "=" or Has_Element, the cursor works normally (it would not be No_Element). We don't want to trigger an exception simply for comparing a bad cursor.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>247.c/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
While it is possible to check for these cases or ensure that cursors survive such operations, in many cases the overhead necessary to make the check (or ensure cursors continue to designate the same element) is substantial in time or space. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Erroneous Execution

<MarginText>248/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>A Cursor value is <em>invalid</em> if any of the following have occurred since it was created: <br /></p>

<MarginText>249/2</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>The vector that contains the element it designates has been finalized;<br /></li>
<MarginText>249.1/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0160-1"]} />
<li>The vector that contains the element it designates has been used as the Target of a call to Assign, or as the target of an <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.2#S0173">assignment_statement</a></code>;<br /></li>
<MarginText>250/2</MarginText>
<li>[The vector that contains the element it designates has been used as the Source or Target of a call to Move;] or <br /></li>
</ul>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>250.a/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="proof">
<strong></strong>Move has been reworded in terms of Assign and Clear, which are covered by other bullets, so this text is redundant. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>251/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0160-1", "AI05-0262-1"]} />
<ul>
<li>The element it designates has been deleted or removed from the vector that previously contained the element. <br /></li>
</ul>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>251.a/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0160-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<strong></strong>An element can be removed via calls to Set_Length, Clear, and Merge; and indirectly via calls to Assign and Move. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>252/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The result of "=" or Has_Element is unspecified if it is called with an invalid cursor parameter. Execution is erroneous if any other subprogram declared in Containers.Vectors is called with an invalid cursor parameter.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>252.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<strong></strong>The list above (combined with the bounded error cases) is intended to be exhaustive. In other cases, a cursor value continues to designate its original element. For instance, cursor values survive the appending of new elements. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>252.1/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<p>Execution is erroneous if the vector associated with the result of a call to Reference or Constant_Reference is finalized before the result object returned by the call to Reference or Constant_Reference is finalized.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>252.b/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<strong></strong>Each object of Reference_Type and Constant_Reference_Type probably contains some reference to the originating container. If that container is prematurely finalized (which is only possible via Unchecked_Deallocation, as accessibility checks prevent passing a container to Reference that will not live as long as the result), the finalization of the object of Reference_Type will try to access a nonexistent object. This is a normal case of a dangling pointer created by Unchecked_Deallocation; we have to explicitly mention it here as the pointer in question is not visible in the specification of the type. (This is the same reason we have to say this for invalid cursors.) <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Implementation Requirements

<MarginText>253/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>No storage associated with a vector object shall be lost upon assignment or scope exit.<br /></p>

<MarginText>254/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0262-1"]} />
<p>The execution of an <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.2#S0173">assignment_statement</a></code> for a vector shall have the effect of copying the elements from the source vector object to the target vector object and changing the length of the target object to that of the source object.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>254.a/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0298-1", "AI12-0005-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>An assignment of a Vector is a &ldquo;deep&rdquo; copy; that is the elements are copied as well as the data structures. We say &ldquo;effect of&rdquo; in order to allow the implementation to avoid copying elements immediately if it wishes. For instance, an implementation that avoided copying until one of the containers is modified would be allowed. (Note that such an implementation would  require care, as Query_Element and Constant_Reference both could be used to access an element which later needs to be reallocated while the parameter or reference still exists, potentially leaving the parameter or reference pointing at the wrong element.) <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Implementation Advice

<MarginText>255/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Containers.Vectors should be implemented similarly to an array. In particular, if the length of a vector is <em>N</em>, then<br /></p>

<MarginText>256/2</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>the worst-case time complexity of Element should be <em>O</em>(log <em>N</em>); <br /></li>
</ul>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>256.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>The worst-case time complexity of Element for Containers.Vector should be <em>O</em>(log <em>N</em>).<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>257/2</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>the worst-case time complexity of Append with Count=1 when <em>N</em> is less than the capacity of the vector should be <em>O</em>(log <em>N</em>); and <br /></li>
</ul>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>257.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>The worst-case time complexity of Append with Count = 1 when <em>N</em> is less than the capacity for Containers.Vector should be <em>O</em>(log <em>N</em>).<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>258/2</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>the worst-case time complexity of Prepend with Count=1 and Delete_First with Count=1 should be <em>O</em>(<em>N</em> log <em>N</em>). <br /></li>
</ul>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>258.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>The worst-case time complexity of Prepend with Count = 1 and Delete_First with Count=1 for Containers.Vectors should be <em>O</em>(<em>N</em> log <em>N</em>).<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>258.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<strong></strong>We do not mean to overly constrain implementation strategies here. However, it is important for portability that the performance of large containers has roughly the same factors on different implementations. If a program is moved to an implementation that takes <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>) time to access elements, that program could be unusable when the vectors are large. We allow <em>O</em>(log <em>N</em>) access because the proportionality constant and caching effects are likely to be larger than the log factor, and we don't want to discourage innovative implementations. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>259/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The worst-case time complexity of a call on procedure Sort of an instance of Containers.Vectors.Generic_Sorting should be <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>**2), and the average time complexity should be better than <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>**2). <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>259.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>The worst-case time complexity of a call on procedure Sort of an instance of Containers.Vectors.Generic_Sorting should be <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>**2), and the average time complexity should be better than <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>**2).<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>259.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<strong></strong>In other words, we're requiring the use of a better than <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>**2) sorting algorithm, such as Quicksort. No bubble sorts allowed! <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>260/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Containers.Vectors.Generic_Sorting.Sort and Containers.Vectors.Generic_Sorting.Merge should minimize copying of elements. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>260.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>Containers.Vectors.Generic_Sorting.Sort and Containers.Vectors.Generic_Sorting.Merge should minimize copying of elements.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>260.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
<strong>To be honest: </strong>We do not mean &ldquo;absolutely minimize&rdquo; here; we're not intending to require a single copy for each element. Rather, we want to suggest that the sorting algorithm chosen is one that does not copy items unnecessarily. Bubble sort would not meet this advice, for instance. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>261/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Move should not copy elements, and should minimize copying of internal data structures. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>261.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>Containers.Vectors.Move should not copy elements, and should minimize copying of internal data structures.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>261.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>Usually that can be accomplished simply by moving the pointer(s) to the internal data structures from the Source vector to the Target vector. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>262/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>If an exception is propagated from a vector operation, no storage should be lost, nor any elements removed from a vector unless specified by the operation. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>262.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>If an exception is propagated from a vector operation, no storage should be lost, nor any elements removed from a vector unless specified by the operation.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>262.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<strong></strong>This is important so that programs can recover from errors. But we don't want to require heroic efforts, so we just require documentation of cases where this can't be accomplished. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>263/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0440-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
NOTE 1   All elements of a vector occupy locations in the internal array. If a sparse container is required, a Hashed_Map can  be used rather than a vector.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
NOTE 2   If Index_Type'Base'First = Index_Type'First an instance of Ada.Containers.Vectors will raise Constraint_Error. A value below Index_Type'First is required so that an empty vector has a meaningful value of Last_Index.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<strong></strong>This property is the main reason why only integer types (as opposed to any discrete type) are allowed as the index type of a vector. An enumeration or modular type would require a subtype in order to meet this requirement. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 95

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.b/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The package Containers.Vectors is new. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Incompatibilities With Ada 2005

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.c/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Subprograms Assign and Copy are added to Containers.Vectors. If an instance of Containers.Vectors is referenced in a <code><a href="../AA-8/AA-8.4#S0235">use_clause</a></code>, and an entity <em>E</em> with the same <code><a href="../AA-3/AA-3.1#S0022">defining_identifier</a></code> as a new entity in Containers.Vectors is defined in a package that is also referenced in a <code><a href="../AA-8/AA-8.4#S0235">use_clause</a></code>, the entity <em>E</em> may no longer be use-visible, resulting in errors. This should be rare and is easily fixed if it does occur. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 2005

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.d/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Added iterator, reference, and indexing support to make vector containers more convenient to use. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Wording Changes from Ada 2005

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.e/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Generalized the definition of Reserve_Capacity and Move. Specified which elements are read/written by stream attributes.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.f/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0022-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<strong></strong> Added a Bounded (Run-Time) Error to cover tampering by generic actual subprograms.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.g/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0027-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<strong></strong> Added a Bounded (Run-Time) Error to cover access to finalized vector containers.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.h/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0044-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<strong></strong> Redefined "{"<"}" actuals to require a strict weak ordering; the old definition allowed indeterminant comparisons that would not have worked in a container.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.i/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0084-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<strong></strong> Added a pragma Remote_Types so that containers can be used in distributed programs.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.j/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0160-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<strong></strong> Revised the definition of invalid cursors to cover missing (and new) cases.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.k/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0265-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<strong></strong> Defined when a container prohibits tampering in order to more clearly define where the check is made and the exception raised. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Inconsistencies With Ada 2012

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.l/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0111-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Tampering with elements is now defined to be equivalent to tampering with cursors for ordinary containers. If a program requires tampering detection to work, it might fail in Ada 2022. Specifically, if a program requires Program_Error to be raised by a routine that (only) tampers with elements in Ada 2012 (such as Replace_Element) when called in a context that does not allow tampering with elements (such as Update_Element), the routine will work as defined instead of raising Program_Error in Ada 2022. Needless to say, this shouldn't happen outside of test programs. Note that such contexts still prohibit tampering with cursors, so routines like Insert and Delete will still raise Program_Error in this case.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.m/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Trying to insert or concatenate more than Count_Type'Last elements will now raise Constraint_Error rather than Capacity_Error. This is extremely unlikely to happen, as Count_Type'Last is typically at least 2**31-1, so most such vectors will exceed memory before reaching this error. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Incompatibilities With Ada 2012

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.n/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0111-1", "AI12-0112-1", "AI12-0339-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
A number of new subprograms, types, and even a nested package were added to Containers.Vectors to better support contracts and stable views. Therefore, a use clause conflict is possible; see the introduction of <a href="../AA-A/">Annex A</a> for more on this topic.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.o/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0005-1", "AI12-0212-1", "AI12-0400-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Vector objects now support aggregates. This introduces a potential incompatibility for overloaded routines, including the "&" operations defined in this package. If the Element_Type of the vector is a type that allows aggregates (such as a record type), then calls to the "&" operations with an aggregate element will become ambiguous in Ada 2022, while they would have been legal in Ada 2012. This can be fixed by qualifying the aggregate with the element type.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.p/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0400-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<strong></strong> The Insert, Append, and Prepend operations that operate on two vectors have been renamed Insert_Vector, Append_Vector, and Prepend_Vector, respectively. This was done in order to eliminate the aggregate ambiguity for the commonly used single element Append and Insert routines. The renamed routines are rarely used in Ada 2012 code, so the impact should be minimal. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 2012

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.q/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0196-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<strong></strong> To_Cursor and Replace_Element are now defined such that they can be used concurrently so long as they operate on different elements. This allows some container operations to be used in parallel without separate synchronization.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.r/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0212-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Vectors now support indexed container aggregates, so <code><a href="../AA-4/AA-4.3#S0106">aggregate</a></code> syntax can be used to create Vectors.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.s/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0266-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The iterator for the entire container now can return a parallel iterator which can be used to process the container in parallel. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Wording Changes from Ada 2012

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.t/4</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0110-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
<strong>Corrigendum:</strong> Clarified that tampering checks precede all other checks made by a subprogram (but come after those associated with the call).<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.u/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Added contracts to this container. This includes describing some of the semantics with pre- and postconditions, rather than English text. Note that the preconditions can be Suppressed (see <a href="../AA-11/AA-11.5">11.5</a>).<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>264.v/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0400-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<strong></strong> Split the Append routine into two routines rather than having a single routine with a default parameter, in order that a routine with the appropriate profile for the Aggregate aspect exists. This change should not change the behavior of any existing code. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<a id="Subclause_A.18.3"></a>

## A.18.3  The Generic Package Containers.Doubly_Linked_Lists

<MarginText>1/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The language-defined generic package Containers.Doubly_Linked_Lists provides private types List and Cursor, and a set of operations for each type. A list container is optimized for insertion and deletion at any position. <br /></p>

<MarginText>2/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>A doubly-linked list container object manages a linked list of internal <em>nodes</em>, each of which contains an element and pointers to the next (successor) and previous (predecessor) internal nodes. A cursor designates a particular node within a list (and by extension the element contained in that node). A cursor keeps designating the same node (and element) as long as the node is part of the container, even if the node is moved in the container.<br /></p>

<MarginText>3/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The <em>length</em> of a list is the number of elements it contains. <br /></p>


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>4/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The generic library package Containers.Doubly_Linked_Lists has the following declaration: <br /></p>

<MarginText>5/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0084-1", "AI05-0212-1", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
with Ada.Iterator_Interfaces;{"\n"}generic{"\n"}   type Element_Type is private;{"\n"}   with function "=" (Left, Right : Element_Type){"\n"}      return Boolean is {"<"}{">"};{"\n"}package Ada.Containers.Doubly_Linked_Lists {"\n"}   with Preelaborate, Remote_Types,{"\n"}        Nonblocking, Global ={">"} in out synchronized is {"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.a/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<strong></strong>For discussion on the reasons and meaning of the specifications of the Global and Nonblocking aspects in this generic package, see the notes on the equivalent operations in the specification of the Containers.Vectors package (see <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.2">A.18.2</a>). <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>6/5</MarginText>

<CodeBlock language="ada">
   type List is tagged private{"\n"}      with Constant_Indexing ={">"} Constant_Reference,{"\n"}           Variable_Indexing ={">"} Reference,{"\n"}           Default_Iterator  ={">"} Iterate,{"\n"}           Iterator_Element  ={">"} Element_Type,{"\n"}           Iterator_View     ={">"} Stable.List,{"\n"}           Aggregate         ={">"} (Empty       ={">"} Empty,{"\n"}                                 Add_Unnamed ={">"} Append),{"\n"}           Stable_Properties ={">"} (Length,{"\n"}                                 Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited,{"\n"}                                 Tampering_With_Elements_Prohibited),{"\n"}           Default_Initial_Condition ={">"}{"\n"}              Length (List) = 0 and then{"\n"}              (not Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (List)) and then{"\n"}              (not Tampering_With_Elements_Prohibited (List)), {"\n"}            Preelaborable_Initialization ;{"\n"}

   function Tampering_With_Elements_Prohibited{"\n"}      (Container : List) return Boolean{"\n"}      with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

   function Constant_Reference (Container : aliased in List;{"\n"}                                Position  : in Cursor){"\n"}      return Constant_Reference_Type{"\n"}      with Pre  ={">"} (Position /= No_Element or else{"\n"}                       raise Constraint_Error) and then{"\n"}                    (Has_Element (Container, Position) or else{"\n"}                       raise Program_Error),{"\n"}           Post   ={">"} Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Container),{"\n"}           Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

   function Reference (Container : aliased in out List;{"\n"}                       Position  : in Cursor){"\n"}      return Reference_Type{"\n"}      with Pre  ={">"} (Position /= No_Element or else{"\n"}                       raise Constraint_Error) and then{"\n"}                    (Has_Element (Container, Position) or else{"\n"}                       raise Program_Error),{"\n"}           Post   ={">"} Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Container),{"\n"}           Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

<p>The actual function for the generic formal function "=" on Element_Type values is expected to define a reflexive and symmetric relationship and return the same result value each time it is called with a particular pair of values. If it behaves in some other manner, the functions Find, Reverse_Find, and "=" on list values return an unspecified value. The exact arguments and number of calls of this generic formal function by the functions Find, Reverse_Find, and "=" on list values are unspecified.<br /></p>

<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<strong></strong>If the actual function for "=" is not symmetric and consistent, the result returned by the listed functions cannot be predicted. The implementation is not required to protect against "=" raising an exception, or returning random results, or any other &ldquo;bad&rdquo; behavior. And it can call "=" in whatever manner makes sense. But note that only the results of Find, Reverse_Find, and List "=" are unspecified; other subprograms are not allowed to break if "=" is bad (they aren't expected to use "="). <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>56/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The type List is used to represent lists. The type List needs finalization (see <a href="../AA-7/AA-7.6">7.6</a>).<br /></p>

<MarginText>57/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Empty_List represents the empty List object. It has a length of 0. If an object of type List is not otherwise initialized, it is initialized to the same value as Empty_List.<br /></p>

<MarginText>58/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>No_Element represents a cursor that designates no element. If an object of type Cursor is not otherwise initialized, it is initialized to the same value as No_Element.<br /></p>

<MarginText>59/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI12-0434-1"]} />
<p>The primitive  "=" operator for type Cursor returns True if both cursors are No_Element, or designate the same element in the same container.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>59.a/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0434-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
<strong>To be honest: </strong>&ldquo;The primitive "=" operator&rdquo; is the one with two parameters of type Cursor which returns Boolean. We're not talking about some other (hidden) primitive function named "=". <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>60/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Execution of the default implementation of the Input, Output, Read, or Write attribute of type Cursor raises Program_Error.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>60.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<strong></strong>A cursor will probably be implemented in terms of one or more access values, and the effects of streaming access values is unspecified. Rather than letting the user stream junk by accident, we mandate that streaming of cursors raise Program_Error by default. The attributes can always be specified if there is a need to support streaming. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>60.1/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1", "AI05-0262-1", "AI12-0437-1"]} />
<p>List'Write for a List object <em>L</em> writes Length(<em>L</em>) elements of the list to the stream. It may also  write additional information about the list.<br /></p>

<MarginText>60.2/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1", "AI05-0262-1"]} />
<p>List'Read reads the representation of a list from the stream, and assigns to <em>Item</em> a list with the same length and elements as was written by List'Write.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>60.b/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<strong></strong>Streaming more elements than the container length is wrong. For implementation implications of this rule, see the Implementation Note in <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.2">A.18.2</a>. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>61/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI12-0111-1", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p>[Some operations  check for &ldquo;tampering with cursors&rdquo; of a container because they depend on the set of elements of the container remaining constant, and others check for &ldquo;tampering with elements&rdquo; of a container because they depend on elements of the container not being replaced.] When tampering with cursors is <em>prohibited</em> for a particular list object <em>L</em>, Program_Error is propagated by the finalization of <em>L</em>[, as well as by a call that passes <em>L</em> to certain of the operations of this package, as indicated by the precondition of such an operation]. Similarly, when tampering with elements is <em>prohibited</em> for <em>L</em>, Program_Error is propagated by a call that passes <em>L</em> to certain of the other operations of this package, as indicated by the precondition of such an operation.<br /></p>

<p><em>Paragraphs 62 through 69 are removed as preconditions now describe these rules.</em> <br /></p>

<MarginText>62/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI12-0111-1", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p> <br /></p>

<MarginText>63/5</MarginText>
<ul>
<li> <br /></li>
</ul>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>63.a/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
<strong>To be honest: </strong> <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>64/5</MarginText>

<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1"]} />
<li> <br /></li>
</ul>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>65.a.1/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<strong></strong>We don't need to explicitly mention <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.2#S0173">assignment_statement</a></code>, because that finalizes the target object as part of the operation, and finalization of an object is already defined as tampering with cursors. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>66/5</MarginText>
<ul>
<li> <br /></li>
</ul>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>66.a/5</MarginText>

<strong></strong> <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>67/5</MarginText>

<li> <br /></li>
</ul>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>69.a/5</MarginText>

</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>69.1/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0265-1", "AI12-0110-1", "AI12-0111-1", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p> <br /></p>
