<MarginText>41/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>An object of type Map contains an expandable hash table, which is used to provide direct access to nodes. The <em>capacity</em> of an object of type Map is the maximum number of nodes that can be inserted into the hash table prior to it being automatically expanded.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>41.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>The expected implementation for a Map uses a hash table which is grown when it is too small, with linked lists hanging off of each bucket. Note that in that implementation a cursor needs a back pointer to the Map object to implement iteration; that could either be in the nodes, or in the cursor object. To provide an average <em>O</em>(1) access time, capacity would typically equal the number of buckets in such an implementation, so that the average bucket linked list length would be no more than 1.0.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>41.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
There is no defined relationship between elements in a hashed map. Typically, iteration will return elements in the order that they are hashed in. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>42/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Two keys <em>K1</em> and <em>K2</em> are defined to be <em>equivalent</em> if Equivalent_Keys (<em>K1</em>, <em>K2</em>) returns True.<br /></p>

<MarginText>43/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The actual function for the generic formal function Hash is expected to return the same value each time it is called with a particular key value. For any two equivalent key values, the actual for Hash is expected to return the same value. If the actual for Hash behaves in some other manner, the behavior of this package is unspecified. Which subprograms of this package call Hash, and how many times they call it, is unspecified.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>43.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>The implementation is not required to protect against Hash raising an exception, or returning random numbers, or any other &ldquo;bad&rdquo; behavior. It's not practical to do so, and a broken Hash function makes the container unusable.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>43.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The implementation can call Hash whenever it is needed; we don't want to specify how often that happens. The result must remain the same (this is logically a pure function), or the behavior is unspecified. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>44/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The actual function for the generic formal function Equivalent_Keys on Key_Type values is expected to return the same value each time it is called with a particular pair of key values. It should define an equivalence relationship, that is, be reflexive, symmetric, and transitive. If the actual for Equivalent_Keys behaves in some other manner, the behavior of this package is unspecified. Which subprograms of this package call Equivalent_Keys, and how many times they call it, is unspecified.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>44.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>As with Hash, the implementation is not required to protect against Equivalent_Keys raising an exception or returning random results. Similarly, the implementation can call this operation whenever it is needed. The result must remain the same (this is a logically pure function), or the behavior is unspecified. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>45/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>If the value of a key stored in a node of a map is changed other than by an operation in this package such that at least one of Hash or Equivalent_Keys give different results, the behavior of this package is unspecified.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>45.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>The implementation is not required to protect against changes to key values other than via the operations declared in the Hashed_Maps package.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>45.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
To see how this could happen, imagine an instance of Hashed_Maps where the key type is an access-to-variable type and Hash returns a value derived from the components of the designated object. Then, any operation that has a key value could modify those components and change the hash value:<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>45.c/2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
Key (Map).Some_Component := New_Value;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>45.d/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
This is really a design error on the part of the user of the map; it shouldn't be possible to modify keys stored in a map. But we can't prevent this error anymore than we can prevent someone passing as Hash a random number generator. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>46/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Which nodes are the first node and the last node of a map, and which node is the successor of a given node, are unspecified, other than the general semantics described in <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.4">A.18.4</a>.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>46.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>Typically the first node will be the first node in the first bucket, the last node will be the last node in the last bucket, and the successor will be obtained by following the collision list, and going to the next bucket at the end of each bucket. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>46.1/5</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Empty (Capacity : Count_Type := implementation-defined){"\n"}   return Map{"\n"}   with Post ={">"}{"\n"}           Capacity (Empty'Result) {">"}= Capacity and then{"\n"}           not Tampering_With_Elements_Prohibited (Empty'Result) and then{"\n"}           not Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Empty'Result) and then{"\n"}           Length (Empty'Result) = 0;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>46.2/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0339-1"]} />
<p>Returns an empty map.<br /></p>

<MarginText>47/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Capacity (Container : Map) return Count_Type{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>48/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Returns the capacity of Container.<br /></p>

<MarginText>49/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Reserve_Capacity (Container : in out Map;{"\n"}                            Capacity  : in     Count_Type){"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} not Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Container){"\n"}                 or else raise Program_Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Container.Capacity {">"}= Capacity;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>50/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Reserve_Capacity allocates a new hash table such that the length of the resulting map can become at least the value Capacity without requiring an additional call to Reserve_Capacity, and is large enough to hold the current length of Container. Reserve_Capacity then rehashes the nodes in Container onto the new hash table. It replaces the old hash table with the new hash table, and then deallocates the old hash table. Any exception raised during allocation is propagated and Container is not modified.<br /></p>

<MarginText>51/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p><em>This paragraph was deleted.</em> <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>51.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>This routine is used to preallocate the internal hash table to the specified capacity such that future Inserts do not require expansion of the hash table. Therefore, the implementation should allocate the needed memory to make that true at this point, even though the visible semantics could be preserved by waiting until enough elements are inserted.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>51.b/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0005-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
While Reserve_Capacity can be used to reduce the capacity of a map, we do not specify whether an implementation actually supports reduction of the capacity. Since the actual capacity can be anything greater than or equal to Capacity, an implementation never has to reduce the capacity.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>51.c/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Reserve_Capacity tampers with the cursors, as rehashing probably will change the order that elements are stored in the map. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>52/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Clear (Container : in out Map){"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} not Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Container){"\n"}                    or else raise Program_Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Capacity (Container) = Capacity (Container)'Old and then{"\n"}                Length (Container) = 0;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>53/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>In addition to the semantics described in <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.4">A.18.4</a>, Clear does not affect the capacity of Container.<br /></p>

<MarginText>53.1/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Assign (Target : in out Map; Source : in Map){"\n"}      with Pre  ={">"} not Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Target){"\n"}                      or else raise Program_Error,{"\n"}           Post ={">"} Length (Source) = Length (Target) and then{"\n"}                   Capacity (Target) {">"}= Length (Source);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>53.2/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1", "AI05-0248-1"]} />
<p>In addition to the semantics described in <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.4">A.18.4</a>, if the length of Source is greater than the capacity of Target, Reserve_Capacity (Target, Length (Source)) is called before assigning any elements.<br /></p>

<MarginText>53.3/5</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Copy (Source : Map; Capacity : Count_Type := 0){"\n"}   return Map{"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} Capacity = 0 or else Capacity {">"}= Length (Source){"\n"}                   or else raise Capacity_Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"}{"\n"}           Length (Copy'Result) = Length (Source) and then{"\n"}           not Tampering_With_Elements_Prohibited (Copy'Result) and then{"\n"}           not Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Copy'Result) and then{"\n"}           Copy'Result.Capacity = (if Capacity = 0 then{"\n"}              Length (Source) else Capacity);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>53.4/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p>Returns a map whose keys and elements are initialized from the keys and elements of Source. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>53.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>In:<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>53.b/2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Move (Target : in out Map;{"\n"}                Source : in out Map);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>53.c/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The intended implementation is that the internal hash table of Target is first deallocated; then the internal hash table is removed from Source and moved to Target. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>54/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Insert (Container : in out Map;{"\n"}                  Key       : in     Key_Type;{"\n"}                  New_Item  : in     Element_Type;{"\n"}                  Position  :    out Cursor;{"\n"}                  Inserted  :    out Boolean){"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} (not Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Container){"\n"}                    or else raise Program_Error) and then{"\n"}                (Length (Container) {"<"}= Count_Type'Last - 1{"\n"}                    or else raise Constraint_Error),{"\n"}        Post ={">"} (declare{"\n"}                   Original_Length : constant Count_Type :={"\n"}                      Length (Container)'Old;{"\n"}                 begin{"\n"}                   Has_Element (Container, Position) and then{"\n"}                  (if Inserted then{"\n"}                     Length (Container) = Original_Length + 1{"\n"}                   else{"\n"}                     Length (Container) = Original_Length)) and then{"\n"}                 Capacity (Container) {">"}= Length (Container);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>55/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>In addition to the semantics described in <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.4">A.18.4</a>, if Length (Container) equals Capacity (Container), then Insert first calls Reserve_Capacity to increase the capacity of Container to some larger value.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>Insert should only compare keys that hash to the same bucket in the hash table.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
We specify when Reserve_Capacity is called to bound the overhead of capacity expansion operations (which are potentially expensive). Moreover, expansion can be predicted by comparing Capacity(Map) to Length(Map). Since we don't specify by how much the hash table is expanded, this only can be used to predict the next expansion, not later ones.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.c/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>In:<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.d/2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Exclude (Container : in out Map;{"\n"}                   Key       : in     Key_Type);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.e/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Exclude should only compare keys that hash to the same bucket in the hash table.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.f/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>In:<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.g/2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Delete (Container : in out Map;{"\n"}                  Key       : in     Key_Type);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.h/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Delete should only compare keys that hash to the same bucket in the hash table. The node containing the element may be deallocated now, or it may be saved and reused later.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.i/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>In:<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.j/2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function First (Container : Map) return Cursor;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.k/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
In a typical implementation, this will be the first node in the lowest numbered hash bucket that contains a node.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.l/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>In:<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.m/2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Next (Position  : Cursor) return Cursor;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.n/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
In a typical implementation, this will return the next node in a bucket; if Position is the last node in a bucket, this will return the first node in the next nonempty bucket.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.o/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
A typical implementation will need to a keep a pointer at the map container in the cursor in order to implement this function. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.p/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>In:<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.q/2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Find (Container : Map;{"\n"}               Key       : Key_Type) return Cursor;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>55.r/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Find should only compare keys that hash to the same bucket in the hash table.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>56/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Equivalent_Keys (Left, Right : Cursor){"\n"}   return Boolean{"\n"}   with Pre    ={">"} (Left /= No_Element and then Right /= No_Element){"\n"}                      or else raise Constraint_Error,{"\n"}        Global ={">"} in all;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>57/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Equivalent to Equivalent_Keys (Key (Left), Key (Right)).<br /></p>

<MarginText>58/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Equivalent_Keys (Left  : Cursor;{"\n"}                          Right : Key_Type) return Boolean{"\n"}   with Pre    ={">"} Left /= No_Element or else raise Constraint_Error,{"\n"}        Global ={">"} in all;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>59/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Equivalent to Equivalent_Keys (Key (Left), Right).<br /></p>

<MarginText>60/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Equivalent_Keys (Left  : Key_Type;{"\n"}                          Right : Cursor) return Boolean{"\n"}   with Pre    ={">"} Right /= No_Element or else raise Constraint_Error,{"\n"}        Global ={">"} in all;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>61/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Equivalent to Equivalent_Keys (Left, Key (Right)).<br /></p>

<MarginText>61.1/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1", "AI12-0266-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Iterate (Container : in Map){"\n"}   return Map_Iterator_Interfaces.Parallel_Iterator 'Class{"\n"}   with Post ={">"} Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Container);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>61.2/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1", "AI05-0265-1", "AI05-0269-1", "AI12-0266-1"]} />
<p>Iterate returns an iterator object (see <a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#Subclause_5.5.1">5.5.1</a>) that will generate a value for a loop parameter (see <a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#Subclause_5.5.2">5.5.2</a>) designating each node in Container, starting with the first node and moving the cursor according to the successor relation when used as a forward iterator, and processing all nodes concurrently when used as a parallel iterator. Tampering with the cursors of Container is prohibited while the iterator object exists (in particular, in the <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.1#S0166">sequence_of_statements</a></code> of the <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#S0178">loop_statement</a></code> whose <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#S0183">iterator_specification</a></code> denotes this object). The iterator object needs finalization.<br /></p>


#### Implementation Advice

<MarginText>62/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>If <em>N</em> is the length of a map, the average time complexity of the subprograms Element, Insert, Include, Replace, Delete, Exclude, and Find that take a key parameter should be <em>O</em>(log <em>N</em>). The average time complexity of the subprograms that take a cursor parameter should be <em>O</em>(1). The average time complexity of Reserve_Capacity should be <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>). <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>62.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>The average time complexity of Element, Insert, Include, Replace, Delete, Exclude, and Find operations that take a key parameter for Containers.Hashed_Maps should be <em>O</em>(log <em>N</em>). The average time complexity of the subprograms of Containers.Hashed_Maps that take a cursor parameter should be <em>O</em>(1). The average time complexity of Containers.Hashed_Maps.Reserve_Capacity should be <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>).<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>62.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<strong></strong>We do not mean to overly constrain implementation strategies here. However, it is important for portability that the performance of large containers has roughly the same factors on different implementations. If a program is moved to an implementation for which Find is <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>), that program could be unusable when the maps are large. We allow <em>O</em>(log <em>N</em>) access because the proportionality constant and caching effects are likely to be larger than the log factor, and we don't want to discourage innovative implementations. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 95

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>62.c/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The generic package Containers.Hashed_Maps is new. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Incompatibilities With Ada 2005

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>62.d/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Subprograms Assign and Copy are added to Containers.Hashed_Maps. If an instance of Containers.Hashed_Maps is referenced in a <code><a href="../AA-8/AA-8.4#S0235">use_clause</a></code>, and an entity <em>E</em> with the same <code><a href="../AA-3/AA-3.1#S0022">defining_identifier</a></code> as a new entity in Containers.Hashed_Maps is defined in a package that is also referenced in a <code><a href="../AA-8/AA-8.4#S0235">use_clause</a></code>, the entity <em>E</em> may no longer be use-visible, resulting in errors. This should be rare and is easily fixed if it does occur. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 2005

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>62.e/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Added iterator and indexing support to make hashed map containers more convenient to use. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Wording Changes from Ada 2005

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>62.f/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0084-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<strong></strong> Added a pragma Remote_Types so that containers can be used in distributed programs. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Incompatibilities With Ada 2012

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>62.g/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0111-1", "AI12-0112-1", "AI12-0339-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
A number of new subprograms, types, and even a nested package were added to Containers.Hashed_Maps to better support contracts and stable views. Therefore, a use clause conflict is possible; see the introduction of <a href="../AA-A/">Annex A</a> for more on this topic. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 2012

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>62.h/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0212-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Maps now support named container aggregates, so <code><a href="../AA-4/AA-4.3#S0106">aggregate</a></code> syntax can be used to create Maps.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>62.i/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0266-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The iterator for the container now can return a parallel iterator which can be used to process the container in parallel. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Wording Changes from Ada 2012

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>62.j/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
Added contracts to this container. This includes describing some of the semantics with pre- and postconditions, rather than English text. Note that the preconditions can be Suppressed (see <a href="../AA-11/AA-11.5">11.5</a>). <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<a id="Subclause_A.18.6"></a>

## A.18.6  The Generic Package Containers.Ordered_Maps


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>1/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />

<MarginText>55/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Two keys <em>K1</em> and <em>K2</em> are <em>equivalent</em> if both <em>K1</em> {"<"} <em>K2</em> and <em>K2</em> {"<"} <em>K1</em> return False, using the generic formal "{"<"}" operator for keys. Function Equivalent_Keys returns True if Left and Right are equivalent, and False otherwise.<br /></p>

<MarginText>56/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0044-1"]} />
<p>The actual function for the generic formal function "{"<"}" on Key_Type values is expected to return the same value each time it is called with a particular pair of key values. It should define a strict weak ordering relationship (see <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18">A.18</a>). If the actual for "{"<"}" behaves in some other manner, the behavior of this package is unspecified. Which subprograms of this package call "{"<"}" and how many times they call it, is unspecified.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>56.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>The implementation is not required to protect against "{"<"}" raising an exception, or returning random results, or any other &ldquo;bad&rdquo; behavior. It's not practical to do so, and a broken "{"<"}" function makes the container unusable.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>56.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The implementation can call "{"<"}" whenever it is needed; we don't want to specify how often that happens. The result must remain the same (this is a logically pure function), or the behavior is unspecified. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>57/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>If the value of a key stored in a map is changed other than by an operation in this package such that at least one of "{"<"}" or "=" give different results, the behavior of this package is unspecified.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>57.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>The implementation is not required to protect against changes to key values other than via the operations declared in the Ordered_Maps package.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>57.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
To see how this could happen, imagine an instance of Ordered_Maps package where the key type is an access-to-variable type and "{"<"}" returns a value derived from comparing the components of the designated objects. Then, any operation that has a key value (even if the key value is constant) could modify those components and change the result of "{"<"}":<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>57.c/2</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
Key (Map).Some_Component := New_Value;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>57.d/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
This is really a design error on the part of the user of the map; it shouldn't be possible to modify keys stored in a map such that "{"<"}" changes. But we can't prevent this error anymore than we can prevent someone passing as "{"<"}" a routine that produces random answers. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>58/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0262-1"]} />
<p>The <em>first node</em> of a nonempty map is the one whose key is less than the key of all the other nodes in the map. The <em>last node</em> of a nonempty map is the one whose key is greater than the key of all the other elements in the map. The <em>successor</em> of a node is the node with the smallest key that is larger than the key of the given node. The <em>predecessor</em> of a node is the node with the largest key that is smaller than the key of the given node. All comparisons are done using the generic formal "{"<"}" operator for keys.<br /></p>

<MarginText>58.1/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Copy (Source : Map){"\n"}   return Map{"\n"}   with Post ={">"}{"\n"}      Length (Copy'Result) = Length (Source) and then{"\n"}      not Tampering_With_Elements_Prohibited (Copy'Result) and then{"\n"}      not Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Copy'Result);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>58.2/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1"]} />
<p>Returns a map whose keys and elements are initialized from the corresponding keys and elements of Source.<br /></p>

<MarginText>59/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Delete_First (Container : in out Map){"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} not Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Container){"\n"}                    or else raise Program_Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} (declare{"\n"}                   Original_Length : constant Count_Type :={"\n"}                      Length (Container)'Old;{"\n"}                 begin{"\n"}                   (if Original_Length = 0 then Length (Container) = 0{"\n"}                    else Length (Container) = Original_Length - 1));{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>60/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0264-1"]} />
<p>If Container is empty, Delete_First has no effect. Otherwise, the node designated by First (Container) is removed from Container. Delete_First tampers with the cursors of Container.<br /></p>

<MarginText>61/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">

</CodeBlock>

<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0264-1"]} />
<p>If Container is empty, Delete_Last has no effect. Otherwise, the node designated by Last (Container) is removed from Container. Delete_Last tampers with the cursors of Container.<br /></p>

<MarginText>73/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Previous (Position : Cursor) return Cursor{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} in all, Use_Formal ={">"} null,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} (if Position = No_Element then{"\n"}                    Previous'Result = No_Element);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>74/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0262-1"]} />
<p>If Position equals No_Element, then Previous returns No_Element. Otherwise, Previous returns a cursor designating the predecessor node of the one designated by Position. If Position designates the first element, then Previous returns No_Element.<br /></p>

<MarginText>74.1/5</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Previous (Container : Map;{"\n"}                   Position : Cursor) return Cursor{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null,{"\n"}        Pre  ={">"} Position = No_Element or else{"\n"}                Has_Element (Container, Position){"\n"}                   or else raise Program_Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} (if Position = No_Element then{"\n"}                   Previous'Result = No_Element{"\n"}                 elsif Previous'Result = No_Element then{"\n"}                   Position = First (Container){"\n"}                 else Has_Element (Container, Previous'Result));{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>74.2/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p>Returns a cursor designating the predecessor of the node designated by Position in Container, if any.<br /></p>

<MarginText>75/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Previous (Position : in out Cursor){"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} in all, Use_Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>76/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Equivalent to Position := Previous (Position).<br /></p>

<MarginText>76.1/5</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Previous (Container : in     Map;{"\n"}                    Position  : in out Cursor){"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null,{"\n"}        Pre  ={">"} Position = No_Element or else{"\n"}                Has_Element (Container, Position){"\n"}                   or else raise Program_Error,{"\n"}        Post ={">"} (if Position /= No_Element{"\n"}                 then Has_Element (Container, Position));{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>76.2/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p>Equivalent to Position := Previous (Container, Position).<br /></p>

<MarginText>77/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Floor (Container : Map;{"\n"}                Key       : Key_Type) return Cursor{"\n"}   with Post ={">"} (if Floor'Result /= No_Element{"\n"}                 then Has_Element (Container, Floor'Result));{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>78/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0264-1"]} />
<p>Floor searches for the last node whose key is not greater than Key, using the generic formal "{"<"}" operator for keys. If such a node is found, a cursor that designates it is returned. Otherwise, No_Element is returned.<br /></p>

<MarginText>79/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Ceiling (Container : Map;{"\n"}                  Key       : Key_Type) return Cursor{"\n"}   with Post ={">"} (if Ceiling'Result /= No_Element{"\n"}                 then Has_Element (Container, Ceiling'Result));{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>80/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0264-1"]} />
<p>Ceiling searches for the first node whose key is not less than Key, using the generic formal "{"<"}" operator for keys. If such a node is found, a cursor that designates it is returned. Otherwise, No_Element is returned.<br /></p>

<MarginText>93/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Reverse_Iterate{"\n"}  (Container : in Map;{"\n"}   Process   : not null access procedure (Position : in Cursor)){"\n"}   with Allows_Exit;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>94/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0212-1"]} />
<p>Iterates over the nodes in Container as per procedure Iterate, with the difference that the nodes are traversed in predecessor order, starting with the last node.<br /></p>

<MarginText>94.1/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1", "AI12-0266-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Iterate (Container : in Map){"\n"}   return Map_Iterator_Interfaces.Parallel_Reversible_Iterator 'Class{"\n"}   with Post ={">"} Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Container);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>94.2/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1", "AI05-0265-1", "AI05-0269-1", "AI12-0266-1"]} />
<p>Iterate returns an  iterator object (see <a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#Subclause_5.5.1">5.5.1</a>) that will generate a value for a loop parameter (see <a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#Subclause_5.5.2">5.5.2</a>) designating each node in Container, starting with the first node and moving the cursor according to the successor relation when used as a forward iterator, and starting with the last node and moving the cursor according to the predecessor relation when used as a reverse iterator, and processing all nodes concurrently when used as a parallel iterator. Tampering with the cursors of Container is prohibited while the iterator object exists (in particular, in the <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.1#S0166">sequence_of_statements</a></code> of the <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#S0178">loop_statement</a></code> whose <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#S0183">iterator_specification</a></code> denotes this object). The iterator object needs finalization.<br /></p>

<MarginText>94.3/5</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Iterate (Container : in Map; Start : in Cursor){"\n"}   return Map_Iterator_Interfaces.Reversible_Iterator'Class{"\n"}   with Pre  ={">"} (Start /= No_Element{"\n"}                   or else raise Constraint_Error) and then{"\n"}                (Has_Element (Container, Start){"\n"}                   or else raise Program_Error),{"\n"}        Post ={">"} Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Container);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>94.4/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0262-1", "AI05-0265-1", "AI05-0269-1", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p> Iterate returns a reversible iterator object (see <a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#Subclause_5.5.1">5.5.1</a>) that will generate a value for a loop parameter (see <a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#Subclause_5.5.2">5.5.2</a>) designating each node in Container, starting with the node designated by Start and moving the cursor according to the successor relation when used as a forward iterator, or moving the cursor according to the predecessor relation when used as a reverse iterator. Tampering with the cursors of Container is prohibited while the iterator object exists (in particular, in the <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.1#S0166">sequence_of_statements</a></code> of the <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#S0178">loop_statement</a></code> whose <code><a href="../AA-5/AA-5.5#S0183">iterator_specification</a></code> denotes this object). The iterator object needs finalization.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>94.a/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<strong></strong>Exits are allowed from the loops created using the iterator objects. In particular, to stop the iteration at a particular cursor, just add <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>94.b/3</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
exit when Cur = Stop;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>94.c/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
in the body of the loop (assuming that Cur is the loop parameter and Stop is the cursor that you want to stop at). <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Implementation Advice

<MarginText>95/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>If <em>N</em> is the length of a map, then the worst-case time complexity of the Element, Insert, Include, Replace, Delete, Exclude, and Find operations that take a key parameter should be <em>O</em>((log <em>N</em>)**2) or better. The worst-case time complexity of the subprograms that take a cursor parameter should be <em>O</em>(1). <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>95.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>The worst-case time complexity of Element, Insert, Include, Replace, Delete, Exclude, and Find operations that take a key parameter for Containers.Ordered_Maps should be <em>O</em>((log <em>N</em>)**2) or better. The worst-case time complexity of the subprograms of Containers.Ordered_Maps that take a cursor parameter should be <em>O</em>(1).<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>95.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>A balanced (red-black) tree for keys has <em>O</em>(log <em>N</em>) worst-case performance. Note that a <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>) worst-case implementation (like a list) would be wrong. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>95.c/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<strong></strong>We do not mean to overly constrain implementation strategies here. However, it is important for portability that the performance of large containers has roughly the same factors on different implementations. If a program is moved to an implementation that takes <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>) to find elements, that program could be unusable when the maps are large. We allow the extra log <em>N</em> factors because the proportionality constant and caching effects are likely to be larger than the log factor, and we don't want to discourage innovative implementations. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
