  function Copy (Source   : Set;{"\n"}                 Capacity : Count_Type := 0) return Map{"\n"}     with Pre  ={">"} Capacity = 0 or else Capacity {">"}= Length (Source){"\n"}                     or else raise Capacity_Error,{"\n"}          Post ={">"} {"\n"}             Length (Copy'Result) = Length (Source) and then{"\n"}             not Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Copy'Result) and then{"\n"}             Copy'Result.Capacity = (if Capacity = 0 then{"\n"}                Length (Source) else Capacity);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>11/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p>Returns a set with key/element pairs initialized from the values in Source.  <br /></p>


#### Bounded (Run-Time) Errors

<MarginText>12/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0160-1", "AI05-0265-1"]} />
<p>It is a bounded error to assign from a bounded set object while tampering with elements [or cursors] of that object is prohibited. Either Program_Error is raised by the assignment, execution proceeds with the target object prohibiting tampering with elements [or cursors], or execution proceeds normally. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.a/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="proof">
<strong></strong>Tampering with elements includes tampering with cursors, so we only really need to talk about tampering with elements here; we mention cursors for clarity. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Erroneous Execution

<MarginText>13/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0265-1"]} />
<p>When a bounded set object <em>S</em> is finalized, if tampering with cursors is prohibited for <em>S</em> other than due to an assignment from another set, then execution is erroneous. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>13.a/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<strong></strong>This is a tampering event, but since the implementation is not allowed to use Ada.Finalization, it is not possible in a pure Ada implementation to detect this error. (There is no Finalize routine that will be called that could make the check.) Since the check probably cannot be made, the bad effects that could occur (such as an iterator going into an infinite loop or accessing a nonexistent element) cannot be prevented and we have to allow anything. We do allow re-assigning an object that only prohibits tampering because it was copied from another object as that cannot cause any negative effects. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Implementation Requirements

<MarginText>14/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0184-1", "AI05-0264-1"]} />
<p>For each instance of Containers.Ordered_Sets and each instance of Containers.Bounded_Ordered_Sets, if the two instances meet the following conditions, then the output generated by the Set'Output or Set'Write subprograms of either instance shall be readable by the Set'Input or Set'Read of the other instance, respectively:<br /></p>

<MarginText>15/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0184-1", "AI05-0248-1"]} />
<ul>
<li>the Element_Type parameters of the two instances are statically matching subtypes of the same type; and<br /></li>
<MarginText>16/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0184-1"]} />
<li>the output generated by Element_Type'Output or Element_Type'Write is readable by Element_Type'Input or Element_Type'Read, respectively (where Element_Type denotes the type of the two actual Element_Type parameters). <br /></li>
</ul>

#### Implementation Advice

<MarginText>17/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1", "AI05-0269-1"]} />
<p>Bounded ordered set objects should be implemented without implicit pointers or dynamic allocation. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>17.a.1/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>Bounded ordered set objects should be implemented without implicit pointers or dynamic allocation.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>18/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1"]} />
<p>The implementation advice for procedure Move to minimize copying does not apply. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>18.a.1/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>The implementation advice for procedure Move to minimize copying does not apply to bounded ordered sets.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>18.a/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1", "AI05-0160-1", "AI05-0184-1"]} />

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>18.b/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0409-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="correction">
<strong></strong>A bounded set now only has Preelaborable_Initialization (abbreviated PI in this note) when the actual for the Element_Type has PI. If an program used a set whose actual Element_Type does not have PI in a context when PI is required (such as a library-level object in a preelaborated unit or as a component of a type with PI), the program would be illegal in Ada 2022 but legal in original Ada 2012. This situation is unlikely, especially as some existing Ada 2012 implementations reject the instance in this case. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

## A.18.25  The Generic Package Containers.Bounded_Multiway_Trees

<MarginText>1/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0136-1"]} />
<p>The language-defined generic package Containers.Bounded_Multiway_Trees provides a private type Tree and a set of operations. It provides the same operations as the package Containers.Multiway_Trees (see <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.10">A.18.10</a>), with the difference that the maximum storage is bounded. <br /></p>


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>2/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0136-1"]} />
<p>The declaration of the generic library package Containers.Bounded_Multiway_Trees has the same contents and semantics as Containers.Multiway_Trees except:<br /></p>

<MarginText>3/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<ul>
<li>The aspect  Preelaborate is replaced with aspect  Pure. Aspect Global is deleted.<br /></li>
<MarginText>4/3</MarginText>
<li>The type Tree is declared with a discriminant that specifies the capacity (maximum number of elements) as follows: <br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>5/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
  type Tree (Capacity : Count_Type) is tagged private... {"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>5.1/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0409-1"]} />
<ul>
<li>The <code><a href="../AA-13/AA-13.1#S0348">aspect_definition</a></code> for Preelaborable_Initialization for type Tree is changed to: <br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>5.2/5</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
  Preelaborable_Initialization ={">"}{"\n"}     Element_Type'Preelaborable_Initialization{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>6/3</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>The type Tree needs finalization if and only if type Element_Type needs finalization.<br /></li>
</ul>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>6.a/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>The type Tree cannot depend on package Ada.Finalization unless the element type depends on that package. The objects returned from the Iterator and Reference functions probably do depend on package Ada.Finalization. Restricted environments may need to avoid use of those functions and their associated types. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>6.1/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0339-1"]} />
<ul>
<li>The function Empty is replaced by:<br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>6.2/5</MarginText>

   function Empty (Capacity : Count_Type := implementation-defined){"\n"}      return Tree{"\n"}      with Post ={">"}{"\n"}            Empty'Result.Capacity = Capacity and then{"\n"}            not Tampering_With_Elements_Prohibited (Empty'Result) and then{"\n"}            not Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Empty'Result) and then{"\n"}            Node_Count (Empty'Result) = 1;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>7/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<ul>

      with Pre ={">"} (not Tampering_With_Cursors_Prohibited (Container){"\n"}                     or else raise Program_Error) and then{"\n"}                  (Node_Count (Container) - 1 {"<"}= Container.Capacity - Count{"\n"}                     or else raise Capacity_Error){"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>8/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<ul>

<MarginText>9/3</MarginText>
<ul>

</CodeBlock>

## A.18.26  Array Sorting

<MarginText>1/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03", "AI05-0001-1"]} />
<p>The language-defined generic procedures Containers.Generic_Array_Sort, Containers.Generic_Constrained_Array_Sort, and Containers.Generic_Sort provide sorting on arbitrary array types. <br /></p>


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>2/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The generic library procedure Containers.Generic_Array_Sort has the following declaration: <br /></p>

<MarginText>3/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
generic{"\n"}   type Index_Type is ({"<"}{">"});{"\n"}   type Element_Type is private;{"\n"}   type Array_Type is array (Index_Type range {"<"}{">"}) of Element_Type;{"\n"}   with function "{"<"}" (Left, Right : Element_Type){"\n"}      return Boolean is {"<"}{">"};{"\n"}procedure Ada.Containers.Generic_Array_Sort (Container : in out Array_Type) {"\n"}   with Pure, Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null ;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>3.a/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<strong></strong>Global ={">"} <strong>null</strong> means that the only global side-effects allowed are associated with the actual generic parameters. Similarly, when Nonblocking is set to True for a generic unit, the only blocking allowed is that associated with the actual generic parameters. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>4/2</MarginText>
<p>Reorders the elements of Container such that the elements are sorted smallest first as determined by the generic formal "{"<"}" operator provided. Any exception raised during evaluation of "{"<"}" is propagated.<br /></p>

<MarginText>5/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0044-1", "AI05-0262-1"]} />
<p>The actual function for the generic formal function "{"<"}" of Generic_Array_Sort is expected to return the same value each time it is called with a particular pair of element values. It should define a strict weak ordering relationship (see <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18">A.18</a>); it should not modify Container. If the actual for "{"<"}" behaves in some other manner, the behavior of the instance of Generic_Array_Sort is unspecified. The number of times Generic_Array_Sort calls "{"<"}" is unspecified.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<strong></strong>This implies swapping the elements, usually including an intermediate copy. This of course means that the elements will be copied. Since the elements are nonlimited, this usually will not be a problem. Note that there is Implementation Advice below that the implementation should use a sort that minimizes copying of elements.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>5.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
The sort is not required to be stable (and the fast algorithm required will not be stable). If a stable sort is needed, the user can include the original location of the element as an extra "sort key". We considered requiring the implementation to do that, but it is mostly extra overhead -- usually there is something already in the element that provides the needed stability. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>6/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The generic library procedure Containers.Generic_Constrained_Array_Sort has the following declaration: <br /></p>

<MarginText>7/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
generic{"\n"}   type Index_Type is ({"<"}{">"});{"\n"}   type Element_Type is private;{"\n"}   type Array_Type is array (Index_Type) of Element_Type;{"\n"}   with function "{"<"}" (Left, Right : Element_Type){"\n"}      return Boolean is {"<"}{">"};{"\n"}procedure Ada.Containers.Generic_Constrained_Array_Sort{"\n"}      (Container : in out Array_Type){"\n"}   with Pure, Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null ;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>7.a/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<strong></strong>Global ={">"} <strong>null</strong> means that the only global side-effects allowed are associated with the actual generic parameters. Similarly, when Nonblocking is set to True for a generic unit, the only blocking allowed is that associated with the actual generic parameters. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>8/2</MarginText>
<p>Reorders the elements of Container such that the elements are sorted smallest first as determined by the generic formal "{"<"}" operator provided. Any exception raised during evaluation of "{"<"}" is propagated.<br /></p>

<MarginText>9/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0044-1", "AI05-0262-1"]} />
<p>The actual function for the generic formal function "{"<"}" of Generic_Constrained_Array_Sort is expected to return the same value each time it is called with a particular pair of element values. It should define a strict weak ordering relationship (see <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18">A.18</a>); it should not modify Container. If the actual for "{"<"}" behaves in some other manner, the behavior of the instance of Generic_Constrained_Array_Sort is unspecified. The number of times Generic_Constrained_Array_Sort calls "{"<"}" is unspecified.<br /></p>

<MarginText>9.1/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1"]} />
<p>The generic library procedure Containers.Generic_Sort has the following declaration: <br /></p>

<MarginText>9.2/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0056-1", "AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
generic{"\n"}   type Index_Type is ({"<"}{">"});{"\n"}   with function Before (Left, Right : Index_Type) return Boolean;{"\n"}   with procedure Swap (Left, Right : in Index_Type);{"\n"}procedure Ada.Containers.Generic_Sort{"\n"}      (First, Last : Index_Type'Base){"\n"}   with Pure, Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null ;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>9.a/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<strong></strong>Global ={">"} <strong>null</strong> means that the only global side-effects allowed are associated with the actual generic parameters. Similarly, when Nonblocking is set to True for a generic unit, the only blocking allowed is that associated with the actual generic parameters. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>9.3/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0001-1", "AI05-0248-1"]} />
<p>Reorders the elements of an indexable structure, over the range First .. Last, such that the elements are sorted in the ordering determined by the generic formal function Before; Before should return True if Left is to be sorted before Right. The generic formal Before compares the elements having the given indices, and the generic formal Swap exchanges the values of the indicated elements. Any exception raised during evaluation of Before or Swap is propagated.<br /></p>

<MarginText>9.4/3</MarginText>
<p>The actual function for the generic formal function Before of Generic_Sort is expected to return the same value each time it is called with index values that identify a particular pair of element values. It should define a strict weak ordering relationship (see <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18">A.18</a>); it should not modify the elements. The actual function for the generic formal Swap should exchange the values of the indicated elements. If the actual for either Before or Swap behaves in some other manner, the behavior of Generic_Sort is unspecified. The number of times the Generic_Sort calls Before or Swap is unspecified.<br /></p>


#### Implementation Advice

<MarginText>10/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>The worst-case time complexity of a call on an instance of Containers.Generic_Array_Sort or Containers.Generic_Constrained_Array_Sort should be <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>**2) or better, and the average time complexity should be better than <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>**2), where <em>N</em> is the length of the Container parameter. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>10.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>Containers.Generic_Array_Sort and Containers.Generic_Constrained_Array_Sort should have an average time complexity better than <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>**2) and worst case no worse than <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>**2).<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>10.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<strong></strong>In other words, we're requiring the use of a sorting algorithm better than <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>**2), such as Quicksort. No bubble sorts allowed! <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>11/2</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI95-00302-03"]} />
<p>Containers.Generic_Array_Sort and Containers.Generic_Constrained_Array_Sort should minimize copying of elements. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>11.a/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>Containers.Generic_Array_Sort and Containers.Generic_Constrained_Array_Sort should minimize copying of elements.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>11.b/2</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
<strong>To be honest: </strong>We do not mean &ldquo;absolutely minimize&rdquo; here; we're not intending to require a single copy for each element. Rather, we want to suggest that the sorting algorithm chosen is one that does not copy items unnecessarily. Bubble sort would not meet this advice, for instance. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>12/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0248-1"]} />
<p>The worst-case time complexity of a call on an instance of Containers.Generic_Sort should be <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>**2) or better, and the average time complexity should be better than <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>**2), where <em>N</em> is the difference between the Last and First parameters plus 1. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.a.1/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>Containers.Generic_Sort should have an average time complexity better than <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>**2) and worst case no worse than <em>O</em>(<em>N</em>**2).<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>13/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0248-1"]} />
<p>Containers.Generic_Sort should minimize calls to the generic formal Swap. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>13.a.1/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>Containers.Generic_Sort should minimize calls to the generic formal Swap.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<a id="Subclause_A.18.27"></a>

## A.18.27  The Generic Package Containers.Synchronized_Queue_Interfaces

<MarginText>1/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>The language-defined generic package Containers.Synchronized_Queue_Interfaces provides interface type Queue, and a set of operations for that type. Interface Queue specifies a first-in, first-out queue. <br /></p>


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>2/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>The generic library package Containers.Synchronized_Queue_Interfaces has the following declaration: <br /></p>

<MarginText>3/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
generic{"\n"}   type Element_Type is private;{"\n"}package Ada.Containers.Synchronized_Queue_Interfaces {"\n"}   with Pure, Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null is {"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>3.a/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<strong></strong>Global ={">"} <strong>null</strong> means that the only global side-effects allowed are associated with the actual generic parameters. Similarly, when Nonblocking is set to True for a generic unit, the only blocking allowed is that associated with the actual generic parameters. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>4/3</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
   type Queue is synchronized interface;{"\n"}
<MarginText>5/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
   procedure Enqueue{"\n"}     (Container : in out Queue;{"\n"}      New_Item  : in     Element_Type) is abstract{"\n"}       with Synchronization ={">"} By_Entry,{"\n"}           Nonblocking ={">"} False,{"\n"}           Global'Class={">"} in out synchronized;{"\n"}
<MarginText>6/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
   procedure Dequeue{"\n"}     (Container : in out Queue;{"\n"}      Element   :    out Element_Type) is abstract{"\n"}       with Synchronization ={">"} By_Entry,{"\n"}           Nonblocking ={">"} False,{"\n"}           Global'Class={">"} in out synchronized;{"\n"}
<MarginText>7/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
   function Current_Use (Container : Queue) return Count_Type is abstract{"\n"}       with Nonblocking, Global'Class ={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}   function Peak_Use (Container : Queue) return Count_Type is abstract{"\n"}       with Nonblocking, Global'Class ={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null,{"\n"}            Post'Class ={">"} Peak_Use'Result {">"}= Current_Use (Container);{"\n"}
<MarginText>8/3</MarginText>
end Ada.Containers.Synchronized_Queue_Interfaces;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>8.1/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<p>The subprogram behavior descriptions given below are the semantics for the corresponding callable entities found in the language-defined generic packages that have a formal package named Queue_Interfaces.<br /></p>

<MarginText>9/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Enqueue{"\n"}  (Container : in out Queue;{"\n"}   New_Item  : in     Element_Type) is abstract{"\n"}   with Synchronization ={">"} By_Entry{"\n"}        Nonblocking ={">"} False,{"\n"}        Global'Class={">"} in out synchronized;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>10/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1", "AI05-0262-1", "AI05-0264-1"]} />
<p>A queue type that implements this interface is allowed to have a bounded <em>capacity</em>. If the queue object has a bounded capacity, and the number of existing elements equals the capacity, then Enqueue blocks until storage becomes available; otherwise, Enqueue does not block. In any case, it then copies New_Item onto the queue.<br /></p>

<MarginText>11/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
procedure Dequeue{"\n"}  (Container : in out Queue;{"\n"}   Element   :    out Element_Type) is abstract{"\n"}   with Synchronization ={">"} By_Entry{"\n"}        Nonblocking ={">"} False,{"\n"}        Global'Class={">"} in out synchronized;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>12/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1", "AI05-0251-1"]} />
<p>If the queue is empty, then Dequeue blocks until an item becomes available. In any case, it then assigns the element at the head of the queue to Element, and removes it from the queue.<br /></p>

<MarginText>13/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Current_Use (Container : Queue) return Count_Type is abstract{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global'Class={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>14/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>Returns the number of elements currently in the queue.<br /></p>

<MarginText>15/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
function Peak_Use (Container : Queue) return Count_Type is abstract{"\n"}   with Nonblocking, Global'Class={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null,{"\n"}         Post'Class ={">"} Peak_Use'Result {">"}= Current_Use (Container);{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>16/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>Returns the maximum number of elements that have been in the queue at any one time.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>17/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0251-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
NOTE   Unlike other language-defined containers, there are no queues whose element types are indefinite. Elements of an indefinite type can be handled by defining the element of the queue to be a holder container (see <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.18">A.18.18</a>) of the indefinite type, or to be an explicit access type that designates the indefinite type.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>17.a/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<strong></strong>There are no indefinite queues, as a useful definition for Dequeue is not possible. Dequeue cannot be a function, as Ada does not have entries that are functions (thus conditional and timed calls would not be possible). Moreover, protected functions do not allow modifying the queue object (thus it doesn't work even if we decided we didn't care about conditional and timed calls). If Dequeue is an entry, then the dequeued object would have to be an <strong>out</strong> parameter and that would require the queue client to guess the tag and constraints of the value that will be dequeued (otherwise Constraint_Error would be raised), and that is rarely going to be possible. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 2005

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>17.b/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1", "AI05-0251-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
 The generic package Containers.Synchronized_Queue_Interfaces is new. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

## A.18.28  The Generic Package Containers.Unbounded_Synchronized_Queues


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>1/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>The language-defined generic package Containers.Unbounded_Synchronized_Queues provides type Queue, which implements the interface type Containers.Synchronized_Queue_Interfaces.Queue.<br /></p>

<MarginText>2/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
with System;{"\n"}with Ada.Containers.Synchronized_Queue_Interfaces;{"\n"}generic{"\n"}   with package Queue_Interfaces is{"\n"}      new Ada.Containers.Synchronized_Queue_Interfaces ({"<"}{">"});{"\n"}   Default_Ceiling : System.Any_Priority := System.Priority'Last;{"\n"}package Ada.Containers.Unbounded_Synchronized_Queues {"\n"}   with Preelaborate,{"\n"}        Nonblocking, Global ={">"} in out synchronized is {"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>2.a/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<strong></strong>For discussion on the reasons and meaning of the specifications of the Global and Nonblocking aspects of this generic package, see the notes on the specification of the Containers.Vectors package (see <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.2">A.18.2</a>). <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>3/3</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
   package Implementation is{"\n"}      ... -- not specified by the language{"\n"}   end Implementation;{"\n"}
<MarginText>4/3</MarginText>
   protected type Queue{"\n"}        (Ceiling : System.Any_Priority := Default_Ceiling){"\n"}           with Priority ={">"} Ceiling is{"\n"}        new Queue_Interfaces.Queue with{"\n"}
<MarginText>5/3</MarginText>
      overriding{"\n"}      entry Enqueue (New_Item : in Queue_Interfaces.Element_Type);{"\n"}      overriding{"\n"}      entry Dequeue (Element : out Queue_Interfaces.Element_Type);{"\n"}
<MarginText>6/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
      overriding{"\n"}      function Current_Use return Count_Type{"\n"}         with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}      overriding{"\n"}      function Peak_Use return Count_Type{"\n"}         with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}
<MarginText>7/3</MarginText>
   private{"\n"}      ... -- not specified by the language{"\n"}   end Queue;{"\n"}
<MarginText>8/3</MarginText>
private{"\n"}
<MarginText>9/3</MarginText>
   ... -- not specified by the language{"\n"}
<MarginText>10/3</MarginText>
end Ada.Containers.Unbounded_Synchronized_Queues;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>11/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>The type Queue is used to represent task-safe queues.<br /></p>

<MarginText>12/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>The capacity for instances of type Queue is unbounded.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.a/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<strong></strong>Enqueue never blocks; if more storage is needed for a new element, it is allocated dynamically. We don't need to explicitly specify that Queue needs finalization, because it is visibly protected. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>12.b/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<strong></strong>Nested package Implementation can be used to declare the types needed to implement the protected type Queue. This nested package is necessary as types cannot be declared in the private part of a protected type, and the types have to be declared within the generic unit in order to depend on the types imported with package Queue_Interfaces. Clients should never depend on the contents of nested package Implementation. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 2005

</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>12.c/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />

 The generic package Containers.Unbounded_Synchronized_Queues is new. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

      overriding{"\n"}      entry Enqueue (New_Item : in Queue_Interfaces.Element_Type);{"\n"}      overriding{"\n"}      entry Dequeue (Element : out Queue_Interfaces.Element_Type);{"\n"}

<MarginText>7/3</MarginText>
   private{"\n"}      ... -- not specified by the language{"\n"}   end Queue;{"\n"}

private{"\n"}

<MarginText>7/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
      overriding{"\n"}      function Current_Use return Count_Type{"\n"}         with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}      overriding{"\n"}      function Peak_Use return Count_Type{"\n"}         with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}
<MarginText>8/3</MarginText>
   private{"\n"}      ... -- not specified by the language{"\n"}   end Queue;{"\n"}
<MarginText>9/3</MarginText>
private{"\n"}
<MarginText>10/3</MarginText>
   ... -- not specified by the language{"\n"}
<MarginText>11/3</MarginText>
end Ada.Containers.Unbounded_Priority_Queues;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>12/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>The type Queue is used to represent task-safe priority queues.<br /></p>

<MarginText>13/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>The capacity for instances of type Queue is unbounded.<br /></p>

<MarginText>14/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>Two elements <em>E1</em> and <em>E2</em> are equivalent if Before(Get_Priority(<em>E1</em>), Get_Priority(<em>E2</em>)) and Before(Get_Priority(<em>E2</em>), Get_Priority(<em>E1</em>)) both return False.<br /></p>

<MarginText>15/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1", "AI05-0248-1"]} />
<p>The actual functions for Get_Priority and Before are expected to return the same value each time they are called with the same actuals, and should not modify their actuals. Before should define a strict weak ordering relationship (see <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18">A.18</a>). If the actual functions behave in some other manner, the behavior of Unbounded_Priority_Queues is unspecified.<br /></p>

<MarginText>16/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>Enqueue inserts an item according to the order specified by the Before function on the result of Get_Priority on the elements; Before should return True if Left is to be inserted before Right. If the queue already contains elements equivalent to New_Item, then it is inserted after the existing equivalent elements.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>16.a/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<strong></strong>Enqueue never blocks; if more storage is needed for a new element, it is allocated dynamically. We don't need to explicitly specify that Queue needs finalization, because it is visibly protected. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>17/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1", "AI05-0251-1", "AI05-0262-1"]} />
<p>For a call on Dequeue_Only_High_Priority, if the head of the nonempty queue is <em>E</em>, and the function Before(At_Least, Get_Priority(<em>E</em>)) returns False, then <em>E</em> is assigned to Element and then removed from the queue, and Success is set to True; otherwise, Success is set to False and Element is unchanged.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>17.a/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0251-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<strong></strong>Unlike Dequeue, Dequeue_Only_High_Priority is not blocking; it always returns immediately. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>17.b/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0251-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<strong></strong>The use of Before is "backwards" so that it acts like "{">"}=" (it is defined similarly to "{">"}"); thus we dequeue only when it is False. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 2005

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>17.c/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1", "AI05-0251-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
 The generic package Containers.Unbounded_Priority_Queues is new. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<a id="Subclause_A.18.31"></a>

## A.18.31  The Generic Package Containers.Bounded_Priority_Queues


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>1/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>The language-defined generic package Containers.Bounded_Priority_Queues provides type Queue, which implements the interface type Containers.Synchronized_Queue_Interfaces.Queue.<br /></p>

<MarginText>2/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
with System;{"\n"}with Ada.Containers.Synchronized_Queue_Interfaces;{"\n"}generic{"\n"}   with package Queue_Interfaces is{"\n"}      new Ada.Containers.Synchronized_Queue_Interfaces ({"<"}{">"});{"\n"}   type Queue_Priority is private;{"\n"}   with function Get_Priority{"\n"}     (Element : Queue_Interfaces.Element_Type) return Queue_Priority is {"<"}{">"};{"\n"}   with function Before{"\n"}     (Left, Right : Queue_Priority) return Boolean is {"<"}{">"};{"\n"}   Default_Capacity : Count_Type;{"\n"}   Default_Ceiling  : System.Any_Priority := System.Priority'Last;{"\n"}package Ada.Containers.Bounded_Priority_Queues {"\n"}   with Preelaborate,{"\n"}        Nonblocking, Global ={">"} in out synchronized is {"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>2.a/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="discussion">
<strong></strong>For discussion on the reasons and meaning of the specifications of the Global and Nonblocking aspects of this generic package, see the notes on the specification of the Containers.Vectors package (see <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.2">A.18.2</a>). <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>3/3</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
   package Implementation is{"\n"}      ... -- not specified by the language{"\n"}   end Implementation;{"\n"}
<MarginText>4/3</MarginText>
   protected type Queue{"\n"}        (Capacity : Count_Type := Default_Capacity;{"\n"}         Ceiling  : System.Any_Priority := Default_Ceiling){"\n"}           with Priority ={">"} Ceiling is{"\n"}      new Queue_Interfaces.Queue with{"\n"}
<MarginText>5/3</MarginText>
      overriding{"\n"}      entry Enqueue (New_Item : in Queue_Interfaces.Element_Type);{"\n"}      overriding{"\n"}      entry Dequeue (Element : out Queue_Interfaces.Element_Type);{"\n"}
<MarginText>6/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1", "AI05-0251-1"]} />
      not overriding{"\n"}      procedure Dequeue_Only_High_Priority{"\n"}        (At_Least : in     Queue_Priority;{"\n"}         Element  : in out Queue_Interfaces.Element_Type;{"\n"}         Success  :    out Boolean);{"\n"}
<MarginText>7/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0112-1"]} />
      overriding{"\n"}      function Current_Use return Count_Type{"\n"}         with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}      overriding{"\n"}      function Peak_Use return Count_Type{"\n"}         with Nonblocking, Global ={">"} null, Use_Formal ={">"} null;{"\n"}
<MarginText>8/3</MarginText>
   private{"\n"}      ... -- not specified by the language{"\n"}   end Queue;{"\n"}
<MarginText>9/3</MarginText>
private{"\n"}
<MarginText>10/3</MarginText>
   ... -- not specified by the language{"\n"}
<MarginText>11/3</MarginText>
end Ada.Containers.Bounded_Priority_Queues;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>12/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>The semantics are the same as for Unbounded_Priority_Queues, except:<br /></p>

<MarginText>13/3</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>The capacity for instances of type Queue is bounded and specified by the discriminant Capacity. <br /></li>
</ul>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>13.a/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="ramification">
<strong></strong>Since this type has a bounded capacity, Enqueue might block if the queue is full. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Implementation Advice

<MarginText>14/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1"]} />
<p>Bounded priority queue objects should be implemented without implicit pointers or dynamic allocation. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>14.a.1/3</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>Bounded priority queue objects should be implemented without implicit pointers or dynamic allocation.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 2005

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>14.a/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0159-1", "AI05-0251-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
 The generic package Containers.Bounded_Priority_Queues is new. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<a id="Subclause_A.18.32"></a>

## A.18.32  The Generic Package Containers.Bounded_Indefinite_Holders

<MarginText>1/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0254-1"]} />
<p>The language-defined generic package Containers.Bounded_Indefinite_Holders provides a private type Holder and a set of operations for that type. It provides the same operations as the package Containers.Indefinite_Holders (see <a href="../AA-A/AA-A.18#Subclause_A.18.18">A.18.18</a>), with the difference that the maximum storage is bounded. <br /></p>


#### Static Semantics

<MarginText>2/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0254-1"]} />
<p>The declaration of the generic library package Containers.Bounded_Indefinite_Holders has the same contents and semantics as Containers.Indefinite_Holders except:<br /></p>

<MarginText>3/5</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>The following is added to the context clause:<br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>4/5</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
   with System.Storage_Elements; use System.Storage_Elements;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>5/5</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>An additional generic parameter follows Element_Type:<br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>6/5</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
   Max_Element_Size_in_Storage_Elements : Storage_Count;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>6.a/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<strong></strong>This value is in Storage_Elements so that it can be used as a discriminant on a storage pool object in the implementation of the object; Ada doesn't allow discriminant dependent components to use formulas.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>6.b/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
This is a generic parameter as it is a property of the Element_Type; the largest possible object of Element_Type is unlikely to be different for different containers, so making it a discriminant (as Capacity is) provides no useful capability. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>7/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0409-1"]} />
<ul>
<li>The <code><a href="../AA-13/AA-13.1#S0348">aspect_definition</a></code> for Preelaborable_Initialization for type Holder is changed to: <br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>8/5</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
  Preelaborable_Initialization ={">"}{"\n"}     Element_Type'Preelaborable_Initialization{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>9/5</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>Add to the precondition of To_Holder and Replace_Element:<br /></li>
</ul>
<MarginText>10/5</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
  and then (New_Item'Size {"<"}={"\n"}               Max_Element_Size_in_Storage_Elements * System.Storage_Unit{"\n"}            or else raise Program_Error){"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>10.a/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<strong></strong>This ensures that an object that won't fit is not inserted into the container. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>


#### Bounded (Run-Time) Errors

<MarginText>11/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0254-1"]} />
<p>It is a bounded error to assign from a bounded holder object while tampering with elements of that object is prohibited. Either Program_Error is raised by the assignment, execution proceeds with the target object prohibiting tampering with elements, or execution proceeds normally. <br /></p>


#### Implementation Requirements

<MarginText>12/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0254-1"]} />
<p>For each instance of Containers.Indefinite_Holders and each instance of Containers.Bounded_Indefinite_Holders, if the two instances meet the following conditions, then the output generated by the Holder'Output or Holder'Write subprograms of either instance shall be readable by the Holder'Input or Holder'Read of the other instance, respectively:<br /></p>

<MarginText>13/5</MarginText>
<ul>
<li>the Element_Type parameters of the two instances are statically matching subtypes of the same type; and<br /></li>
<MarginText>14/5</MarginText>
<li>the output generated by Element_Type'Output or Element_Type'Write is readable by Element_Type'Input or Element_Type'Read, respectively (where Element_Type denotes the type of the two actual Element_Type parameters). <br /></li>
</ul>

#### Implementation Advice

<MarginText>15/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0254-1"]} />
<p>Bounded holder objects should be implemented without dynamic allocation and any finalization should be trivial unless Element_Type needs finalization. <br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>15.a.1/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-advice">
<strong></strong>Bounded holder objects should be implemented without dynamic allocation.<br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>15.a/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
<strong>To be honest: </strong>Implementation of this container in Ada will probably require the use of a special storage pool. When we say "without dynamic allocation", we mean that this pool does not use heap memory and has a trivial finalization routine (that is, procedures Adjust and Finalize are null procedures). All storage pools are controlled, so we can't reasonably say that a bounded holder will not need finalization. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>15.b/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="implementation-note">
<strong></strong>If the implementation supports discontiguous objects that require multiple calls to Allocate in a storage pool, the storage pool will need to support such allocations. The storage pool implementation can assume that all Allocate calls occur together, and similarly for Deallocate calls, thus simplifying the pool implementation so that allocation only occurs at a high-water mark location. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<MarginText>16/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0350-1", "AI12-0445-1"]} />
<p>The  about the Move and Swap operations is deleted for bounded holders; these operations can copy elements as necessary.<br /></p>

<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>16.a/5</MarginText>
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="reason">
<strong></strong>The memory of a bounded indefinite holder belongs directly to the container, so it cannot be moved with the element. If the element type contains any internal pointers, moving it without calling Adjust would leave such pointers pointing to the wrong holder object. Thus, a full copy is needed, including any associated finalization and adjustments. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Extensions to Ada 2012

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>16.b/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0254-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
 The generic package Containers.Bounded_Indefinite_Holders is new. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>

<a id="Subclause_A.18.33"></a>

## A.18.33  Example of Container Use


#### Examples

<MarginText>1/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<p>The following example is an implementation of Dijkstra's shortest path algorithm in a directed graph with positive distances. The graph is represented by a map from nodes to sets of edges.<br /></p>

<MarginText>2/3</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
with Ada.Containers.Vectors;{"\n"}with Ada.Containers.Doubly_Linked_Lists;{"\n"}use Ada.Containers;{"\n"}generic{"\n"}   type Node is range {"<"}{">"};{"\n"}package Shortest_Paths is{"\n"}   type Distance is new Float range 0.0 .. Float'Last;{"\n"}   type Edge is record{"\n"}      To, From : Node;{"\n"}      Length   : Distance;{"\n"}   end record;{"\n"}
<MarginText>3/3</MarginText>
   package Node_Maps is new Vectors (Node, Node);{"\n"}   -- The algorithm builds a map to indicate the node used to reach a given{"\n"}   -- node in the shortest distance.{"\n"}
<MarginText>4/3</MarginText>
   package Adjacency_Lists is new Doubly_Linked_Lists (Edge);{"\n"}   use Adjacency_Lists;{"\n"}
<MarginText>5/3</MarginText>
   package Graphs is new Vectors (Node, Adjacency_Lists.List);{"\n"}
<MarginText>6/3</MarginText>
   package Paths is new Doubly_Linked_Lists (Node);{"\n"}
<MarginText>7/3</MarginText>
   function Shortest_Path{"\n"}     (G : Graphs.Vector; Source : Node; Target : Node) return Paths.List{"\n"}      with Pre ={">"} G (Source) /= Adjacency_Lists.Empty_List;{"\n"}
<MarginText>8/3</MarginText>
end Shortest_Paths;{"\n"}
<MarginText>9/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0178-1"]} />
package body Shortest_Paths is{"\n"}   function Shortest_Path{"\n"}     (G : Graphs.Vector; Source : Node; Target : Node) return Paths.List{"\n"}   is{"\n"}      use  Node_Maps, Paths, Graphs;{"\n"}      Reached  : array (Node) of Boolean := (others ={">"} False);{"\n"}      -- The set of nodes whose shortest distance to the source is known.{"\n"}
<MarginText>10/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0299-1"]} />
      Reached_From : array (Node) of Node;{"\n"}      So_Far   : array (Node) of Distance := (others ={">"} Distance'Last);{"\n"}      The_Path : Paths.List := Paths.Empty_List;{"\n"}      Nearest_Distance : Distance;{"\n"}      Next     : Node;{"\n"}   begin{"\n"}      So_Far(Source)  := 0.0;{"\n"}
<MarginText>11/3</MarginText>
      while not Reached(Target) loop{"\n"}         Nearest_Distance := Distance'Last;{"\n"}
<MarginText>12/3</MarginText>
         -- Find closest node not reached yet, by iterating over all nodes.{"\n"}         -- A more efficient algorithm uses a priority queue for this step.{"\n"}
<MarginText>13/3</MarginText>
         Next := Source;{"\n"}         for N in Node'First .. Node'Last loop{"\n"}            if not Reached(N){"\n"}              and then So_Far(N) {"<"} Nearest_Distance then{"\n"}                 Next := N;{"\n"}                 Nearest_Distance := So_Far(N);{"\n"}            end if;{"\n"}         end loop;{"\n"}
<MarginText>14/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0299-1"]} />
         if Nearest_Distance = Distance'Last then{"\n"}            -- No next node found, graph is not connected{"\n"}            return Paths.Empty_List;{"\n"}
<MarginText>15/3</MarginText>
         else{"\n"}            Reached(Next) := True;{"\n"}         end if;{"\n"}
<MarginText>16/3</MarginText>
         -- Update minimum distance to newly reachable nodes.{"\n"}
<MarginText>17/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0299-1"]} />
         for E of G (Next) loop{"\n"}            if not Reached(E.To) then{"\n"}               Nearest_Distance := E.Length + So_Far(Next);{"\n"}
<MarginText>18/3</MarginText>
               if Nearest_Distance {"<"} So_Far(E.To) then{"\n"}                  Reached_From(E.To) := Next;{"\n"}                  So_Far(E.To) := Nearest_Distance;{"\n"}               end if;{"\n"}            end if;{"\n"}         end loop;{"\n"}      end loop;{"\n"}
<MarginText>19/3</MarginText>
      -- Rebuild path from target to source.{"\n"}
<MarginText>20/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0386-1"]} />
      declare{"\n"}         N : Node := Target;{"\n"}      begin{"\n"}         Prepend (The_Path, N);{"\n"}         while N /= Source loop{"\n"}            N := Reached_From(N);{"\n"}            Prepend (The_Path, N);{"\n"}         end loop;{"\n"}      end;{"\n"}
<MarginText>21/3</MarginText>
      return The_Path;{"\n"}   end;{"\n"}end Shortest_Paths;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>22/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<p>Note that the effect of the Constant_Indexing aspect (on type Vector) and the Implicit_Dereference aspect (on type Reference_Type) is that<br /></p>

<MarginText>23/3</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
G (Next){"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>24/5</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1", "AI12-0426-1"]} />
<p>is a convenient shorthand  for<br /></p>

<MarginText>25/3</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
G.Constant_Reference (Next).Element.all{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>26/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<p>Similarly, the effect of the loop:<br /></p>

<MarginText>27/3</MarginText>
<CodeBlock language="ada">
for E of G (Next) loop{"\n"}   if not Reached(E.To) then{"\n"}      ...{"\n"}   end if;{"\n"}end loop;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>28/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<p>is the same as:<br /></p>

<MarginText>29/4</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0080-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
for C in G (Next).Iterate loop{"\n"}   declare{"\n"}      E : Edge renames G (Next)(C);{"\n"}   begin{"\n"}      if not Reached(E.To) then{"\n"}         ...{"\n"}      end if;{"\n"}   end;{"\n"}end loop;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<MarginText>30/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<p>which is the same as:<br /></p>

<MarginText>31/4</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI12-0080-1"]} />
<CodeBlock language="ada">
declare{"\n"}   L : Adjacency_Lists.List renames G (Next);{"\n"}   C : Adjacency_Lists.Cursor := L.First;{"\n"}begin{"\n"}   while Has_Element (C) loop{"\n"}      declare{"\n"}         E : Edge renames L(C);{"\n"}      begin{"\n"}         if not Reached(E.To) then{"\n"}            ...{"\n"}         end if;{"\n"}      end;{"\n"}      C := L.Next (C);{"\n"}   end loop;{"\n"}end;{"\n"}

</CodeBlock>
<AnnotatedOnly>

#### Wording Changes from Ada 2005

</AnnotatedOnly>
<AnnotatedOnly>
<MarginText>31.a/3</MarginText>
<MarginInfo items={["AI05-0212-1"]} />
<Admonition type="aarm" aarm="note">
This example of container use is new. <br /></Admonition>
</AnnotatedOnly>
